text: hi everyone agony sad tan oh here the
Internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for us to get together relax and
partake in a review of the new Sun Kil
moon record Benji
Sun Kil moon is the long-running
singer/songwriter project of guitarist
actor and lyricist Marc cosmic too many
fans of underground music and indie rock
and slow Court he is most famously known
for his part in the band red house
painters Andy has a pretty sizable
catalog of albums under his own name
along with a few collaborative LPS as
well the guys had a really steady output
since he was originally signed to a
record label in the early 90s a little
fun fact that I know because he sings
about it on this record among many other
things Marcus had a very long career of
writing songs some of which are very
long detail-oriented and kind of wordy
and this is a role he's grown more and
more comfortable with as he's released
more material under the Sun Kil moon
name and now he's at a point where it
seems like if he writes a song about two
lovers fighting that he would spend at
least a verse or two telling you what
time of day it is what the weather is
their cat's name he would list out at
least three movies from their DVD
collection he's put out songs recently
as well that seemed to be just
unashamedly meta and singing about his
mindset when writing songs are sort of
the songwriting process or the lifestyle
it has put him in or he throws out these
personal stories that seem almost
completely unedited in terms of
information there isn't anything that
mark is afraid to put into these tracks
in terms of wow this is too personal oh
this might be embarrassing there are
tracks on this guy's last LP like among
the leaves such as track 8 which is
actually not track 8 on the songs track
list but it is still a song about his
life as a singer-songwriter the business
the process he touches down on some of
these same themes as well on the track
UK blues where he is singing about just
not having a good time while touring
internationally being heckled having
difficult performances being homesick
among the leaves was a really in
interesting record for mark because of
how deep it sort of let you into just
about every thought in his mind but it
was a less direct album when compared
with other red house painter records and
Sun Kil moon records as well also marks
vocal style on this LP felt really tired
Haggard kind of aged but this album also
had a really uniquely intimate charm to
it as well the songs on this LP meander
and Mark's thoughts wander and I think
that makes these songs lose a little bit
of impact however with this new LP from
Sun Kil moon Benjie this LP is like a
more gratifying take on this incredibly
long-winded songwriting style every song
on this LP seems so off-the-cuff and yet
all the tracks feel so purposefully
fantastic it's almost as if this LP is
the result of Mark writing hundreds upon
hundreds of very wordy rambling songs
just like these and then whittling all
of them down to just the best ones
I think Benji is so good that it could
potentially become one of those gateway
drug albums into the rest of Mark's
discography in which there are a lot of
great records but you know every great
artist every once in a while will put
out one record that sort of seems to
stand tall as a pinnacle and sort of
grabs them a whole new fan base
I think Benji has tons of charm and tons
of appeal even if on the surface it
seems like mark is only doing half of
the job of what we expect from a
singer-songwriter and what we expect is
for a singer-songwriter to go through a
significant emotional experience and
then report back with the most
interesting bits and then condense them
down into a metaphor that we can relate
to comforting us as we move through this
journey called life where we have no
idea what we're doing instead of this
Mark gives us an incredibly
comprehensive account of something that
may have happened to him or another
event of some sort leaving in pieces
that may not necessarily be all that
interesting or purposeful and then
asking the audience to draw some kind of
message or metaphor or meaning from it
like on the closing track here Ben's my
friend where Mark seems to be singing
about just having an average day eating
out with his girlfriend ordering crab
cakes he goes to see
the Postal Service play live he's kind
of in the midst of this middle-aged funk
and I think the song dogs is worth
mentioning off of this LP - which seems
like a list of every significant sexual
experience that Mark had growing up
keep in mind much of the time mark is
singing these songs with a vocal
delivery that only seems a shade or two
away from spoken word and all of Mark's
words are backed up with very warm
classical guitars that nice nylon string
sound and very gentle folk rock
instrumentation background vocals
upright bass drums all feels really
tender and sort of rickety and organic
and I think overall this LP is really
well put together instrumentally there
are a lot of parts here musically that
that hit me that move me like the dreary
vocal harmonies on the track Carissa the
Erie harmonized guitar leads at the end
of the song Newtown the the booming
drums that pop in on the second half of
the song dogs the electric piano on the
song Jim wise has a really nice slow
patient pace to it that sets the tone
for the song perfectly the sax on bends
my friend stellar and the layers of
fluttering guitars that create this
beautiful interlude on the end of the
song the song remains the same all this
instrumentation is a fantastic
foundation for the stories on this
record which essentially are what
captivated me the most they're all
heartbreaking they're all thoughtful and
and relatable - when given some
contemplation like on the track Carissa
where he is singing about the sudden
death of his second cousin and even
though he has very few and faint
memories of her he still feels compelled
to write a song for her and create some
kind of tribute in memory of her and
he's singing about her kids and how she
died and how his family is grieving
oddly enough she passed away in roughly
the same way that marks uncle did as
well an exploding aerosol can in the
trash a story he tells a little deeper
into this album on the track truck
driver mark tributes his parents
beautifully on this record as well with
two separate tracks I can't live without
my mother's love and I
my dad the song about his mother saying
he needs her love there he needs her
friendship her companionship he defends
her and he dreads the day that she's
going to pass away and on the track
about his father Mark's angle changes a
little bit to something more nostalgic
where he's singing about all of these
life lessons and experiences he had with
his dad it's more of a musical portrait
of his father and mark's past with his
father versus what he gets from his dad
right now
and all this reminiscing over the past
seems really great but these tracks
really seem to make sense with the theme
of the album and what mark's mindset is
when these songs are sort of backed up
against tracks like ben's my friend and
richard Vermeer's died today of natural
causes songs that are mired in a slew of
fleeting thoughts and personal musings
but are really reflections on one's own
mortality via aches and pains and
fatigue and sudden death and the song
bends my friend in a way is sort of
about being in that funk created and
caused by all of those things and
pushing past it being competitive even
the satellite stories on this LP that
don't directly play into these themes
are fantastic like the song Jim wise
which is essentially about a friend of
marks fathers who mercy killed his wife
and now is sort of under house arrest
and will most likely be in jail very
soon due to the choice that he made and
mark describes Jim wise from beard to
ankle bracelet and the song Micah lean
is a beautiful little track about three
different people in Mark's life over the
course of different ages who were only
wanting to live like anyone else but for
whatever reason they sort of incurred
serious misfortune Micah lean herself
being disabled mentally one of mark's
friends dying suddenly a bit open mark's
grandmother being diagnosed with cancer
nothing not to make this entire LP just
seem like this really depressing
terrible awful melancholy thing i mean
you know there's definitely sadness on
this LP there's definitely moments on
here where no matter how old you are
you're going to be facing your mortality
a little bit on this
LP not everyone gets a fair chance in
life or a fair shot some people's
opportunities are sort of cut short
unfortunately but there's something sort
of comforting about mark tearing open
this middle-aged man thoughts closet and
just ripping out all the skeletons he's
just getting a lot of things that people
actually think and feel and experience
out there in the open and again it all
feels so relatable and it all feels so
real despite mark being so specific with
these stories that he's the only person
a really experienced or you know saw
heard any of it firsthand we're only
sort of experiencing it through his
lyrics but still
oddly enough with a really low-key
instrumentation and Mark's rambling very
wordy lyrics on this record this LP is
one of the easiest hours of music I've
ever sat through not a moment did I feel
like wow I really want this to be over
there there are a few moments on this LP
where I wish the vocals were a little
bit more intelligible I do wish overall
that the instrumentation was a bit more
varied that the end of the closing track
on here was a bit more final and I do
think the song remains the same like the
movie itself is just a tad long-winded
but still I thought this was a fantastic
record and will no doubt be one of my
favorites of the year I'm feeling a
decent a strong 9 on this thing
transition if you've given this record a
listen what did you think of it did you
love it hate it why what do you think I

Fantana Sun Kil moon forever
